title: Synergetic effects of potassium and biochar on morphological, physiological, and biochemical attributes of maize crop grown under different levels of drought stress
authors: Shafeeq Ur Rahman, Jing-Cheng Han, Ghulam Yasin, Muhammad Talha Imtiaz, Xu Zhao, Sulaiman Ali Alharbi, Saleh Alfarraj, Abdullah A. Alarfaj
keyAssumptions: Single amendments (biochar OR potassium) sufficient for drought mitigation; Individual soil treatments adequate for stress tolerance
citation: Rahman, S. U., Han, J. C., Yasin, G., Imtiaz, M. T., Zhao, X., Alharbi, S. A., Alfarraj, S., & Alarfaj, A. A. (2025). Synergetic effects of potassium and biochar on morphological, physiological, and biochemical attributes of maize crop grown under different levels of drought stress. BMC Plant Biology, 25, 402.
notes: Demonstrates synergistic effects of biochar + potassium combination outperform individual treatments. Key finding: 20 t/ha biochar with optimal K provides superior drought tolerance through improved water retention, reduced oxidative stress, enhanced chlorophyll content.

title: Amelioration of Drought Tolerance in Maize Using Rice Husk Biochar
authors: Md. Abdul Mannan, Mariam Akter Shashi
keyAssumptions: Drought mitigation requires expensive infrastructure or genetic modification; Agricultural waste has limited value for soil improvement
citation: Mannan, M. A., & Shashi, M. A. (2020). Amelioration of Drought Tolerance in Maize Using Rice Husk Biochar. IntechOpen.
notes: Agricultural waste (rice husk) biochar at 20 t/ha provides optimal drought tolerance. Reduced proline content, enhanced chlorophyll, improved water-use efficiency. Validates locally-sourced biochar approach.

title: Improving maize yield and drought tolerance in field conditions through activated biochar application
keyAssumptions: Laboratory results translate directly to field conditions; Conventional biochar sufficient without activation processes
citation: El-Sheikh, M. A., et al. (2024). Improving maize yield and drought tolerance in field conditions through activated biochar application. Scientific Reports, 14, 24618.
notes: Field validation shows activated biochar outperforms conventional biochar. Enhanced soil structure, water retention, crop water-use efficiency under realistic farming conditions. Bridges lab-to-field gap.

title: Impact of biochar on water retention of two agricultural soils – A multi-scale analysis
authors: Daoyuan Wang, Chongyang Li, Sanjai J Parikh, Kate M Scow
keyAssumptions: Single-scale studies adequate for biochar recommendations; Laboratory water retention translates to field benefits; Biochar effects are permanent
citation: Wang, D., Li, C., Parikh, S. J., & Scow, K. M. (2019). Impact of biochar on water retention of two agricultural soils – A multi-scale analysis. Geoderma, 340, 57-68.
notes: Multi-scale analysis reveals biochar benefits are scale-dependent and temporary. High surface area biochar with large particles (≥1 mm) most effective in sandy soils. Benefits diminish as pores fill over time.

title: Effects of pyrolysis temperature on the hydrologically relevant porosity of willow biochar
authors: Jari Hyväluoma, Markus Hannula, Kai Arstila, Hailong Wang, Sampo Kulju, Kimmo Rasa
keyAssumptions: Higher pyrolysis temperature improves plant-available water storage; Pyrogenetic porosity increase translates to water retention benefits
citation: Hyväluoma, J., Hannula, M., Arstila, K., Wang, H., Kulju, S., & Rasa, K. (2018). Effects of pyrolysis temperature on the hydrologically relevant porosity of willow biochar. arXiv:1810.07417 [cond-mat.mtrl-sci].
notes: X-ray tomography reveals feedstock properties determine water-relevant porosity more than pyrolysis temperature. Challenges temperature-centric optimization approach for agricultural applications.

title: Influence of feedstocks and pyrolysis on biochar's capacity to modify soil water retention characteristics
keyAssumptions: Biochar water retention primarily due to porosity; Limited consideration of feedstock-pyrolysis method interactions
citation: Gundale, M., et al. (2015). Influence of feedstocks and pyrolysis on biochar's capacity to modify soil water retention characteristics. Journal of Hydrology, 525, 672-679.
notes: Fast pyrolysis biochars from corn stover and switchgrass superior for plant available water. Provides 1.4-2.6 days additional water availability. Systematic feedstock-pyrolysis method comparison approach.
